entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q4-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
Happy New Year and cheers to a sustainable year ahead! As we kick off 2026, I’m back with my quarterly blog series about the latest innovations and highlights in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Multi-Impact Categories
  • Streamlined Energy Management
  • Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections
  • Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide
  • BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Additional Information

 

Multi-Impact Categories

One of the most significant innovations this quarter is the introduction of multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, moving the product beyond carbon. Built on the same ERP-driven data foundation, governance model, and auditability, the latest updates extend the calculation engine to cover additional environmental impact categories. This lets you monitor a broader spectrum of environmental pressures without changing the way you integrate data or run calculations.

Think of multi-impact categories as different lenses on how your operations affect the Earth system. Aligned with planetary boundaries, they translate the data you already have into indicators for climate and other dimensions like land use, biosphere integrity, and biogeochemical flows. That means you can see where improvements in one area risk shifting burdens elsewhere – and manage those trade-offs with real numbers.

This matters for reporting because one consistent dataset can now serve multiple frameworks (e.g., CSRD, SBTi FLAG), reducing parallel tools and strengthening credibility with synchronized, audit-ready figures for sustainability, finance, and controlling. But this also matters for decision-making because placing multi‑impact indicators alongside financial and operational KPIs brings sustainability into core business steering. A richer picture of environmental pressure helps identify where reductions also improve efficiency, resilience, and brand value – and where hidden risks accumulate. This supports a shift from compliance‑driven reporting to performance‑driven management, where sustainability becomes a source of competitiveness and innovation.

Importantly, nothing changes in how you run the system. You still reuse ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre‑delivered factors, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that the same setup now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so your existing data and methods serve a growing list of corporate and product requirements – without extra integrations or parallel logic.

Footprint Results with additional Impact Categories

To learn more about this innovation, its business rationale, and how it supports your reporting requirements, check out my deep dive blog post: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. It also includes a step-by-step walkthrough of the overall workflow and the enhanced apps. For complete documentation and technical details, visit SAP Help: Calculating Footprints for Different Impact Categories.

We will also publish additional blog posts in the SAP Community, explaining in detail how you can map the multi-impact calculation results to various reporting requirements. Stay tuned!

 

Streamlined Energy Management

Managing energy data for footprint calculations has often been repetitive and time-consuming. Previously, you had to enter the same energy data and meter readings multiple times for different calculation variants, making workflows cumbersome and prone to errors. This complexity increased further when handling periodic meter readings and energy bills across multiple locations.

With the latest release, we’ve simplified this process significantly: For all newly created footprint calculations, energy bills and meter readings are now managed separately from the footprint inventory using two new types of GHG data forms. This means you can collect periodic energy data via the Record GHG Data app and reuse it across multiple calculations without redundant entries. Data maintenance is now independent of calculation variants, saving time and improving consistency.

We’ve also introduced more flexibility: you can calculate energy-related footprints based on energy sources only, without the need for an energy flow model, which is a major advantage for Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations. The user experience has been improved in the Calculate Footprints app as well, with data readings displayed directly on the first page of the inventory for quick access.

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and what has changed in the existing apps. For the full documentation, see Maintain Energy Bills and Meter Readings Using GHG Data Forms on SAP Help.

To use the new approach, start by preparing your footprint inventory scope. In the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app, activate form-based data collection for energy bills and meter readings. If you plan to use meter readings in your energy flow model, make sure to include Direct Emissions and Energy Consumptions under Value Chain Steps. For energy bills, this step isn’t required.

Define Footprint Inventory Scope with Form-Based Data Collection

Next, configure your energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. When creating an energy source, choose Enter Energy Bills if you want to manage consumption through the Energy Bills form, or Use Meter Readings and Planned Consumptions for meter-based data. Meters themselves are created in the Manage Locations app and must be assigned to the relevant plants. If you include meters in your energy flow model, they need to be in place before creating the footprint inventory.

With the scope and energy sources ready, create GHG data collections for the relevant plants and periods in the Manage GHG Data Collections app. Then, record your periodic energy data in the Record GHG Data app. You can enter values directly in the UI. Alternatively, you can download the template for offline editing and mass upload, or you can use the enhanced API for automating data entry and connecting smart meters – see the following chapter for details. Validation checks help ensure consistency, for example by flagging deviations greater than 30% from previous readings.

Record Meter Readings in GHG Data Form

Finally, run your calculation in the Calculate Footprints app. Newly created inventories no longer show separate tabs for energy bills and meter readings – instead, these values are maintained in the GHG data forms, and the Data Readiness section provides an overview of form status and associated models.

Calculate Footprints: Data Readiness

 

Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections

Managing GHG data across multiple locations and form types can be a challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. That’s why we’re introducing a powerful new capability, allowing mass upload for GHG data forms. You can now upload different types of forms – such as energy bills, meter readings, business activities, and waste data – across locations using a single template in the Record GHG Data and Manage GHG Data Collections apps. The template includes tabs for each form type, making it easy to consolidate and manage data efficiently without repetitive manual entry. For all details, check SAP Help: Working with GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

To take automation even further, the GHG Data Forms API has been enhanced with new endpoints and parameters for mass updates. This means you can retrieve and update forms programmatically, integrate with external systems, and even connect smart meters or IoT devices directly. Check out the API on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: GHG Data Forms.

These improvements reduce manual effort, increase accuracy, and save time. They’re also addressing several of the most requested features on SAP Influence.

 

Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements

High‑quality emission factors are the backbone of accurate and audit‑ready footprint results. The broader and better your factor library, the fewer workarounds you need, the faster you can onboard, and the more confidently you can answer customer and regulatory requests. Last quarter, we’ve expanded the default datasets, improved import templates and governance, and refined AI‑assisted mapping – so you can source, structure, and apply factors with less manual effort and higher precision.

With this release, the Manage Emission Factors app expands its default dataset substantially. We’ve added two new source packages and refreshed an existing one to broaden coverage and improve alignment with logistics and fuel methodologies. Newly added are:

  • GLEC Framework (Smart Freight Centre): Harmonized logistics factors across road, rail, air, ocean/inland waterways, and parcel/last‑mile; coverage for fuels and energy (TTW/WTT), logistics sites and equipment (warehousing, refrigeration, handling), plus rules for distance, allocation, and data quality aligned with ISO 14083.
  • German Environment Agency (Umweltbundesamt, UBA): Factors for fossil fuels including natural gas, hard coal, lignite, heating oils, diesel, gasoline, LPG, and more.

In addition, the UK DEFRA packages have been updated and now include the full set of emission factors. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data on SAP Help.

To make onboarding and governance smoother, and to align with the latest features, we’ve updated the import templates in the Manage Emission Factors app. The simple template (v3) and the LCA template (v5) now support impact categories beyond Climate Change, including the selection of an LCIA method and its characterization factor per dataset – so you can manage multi‑impact content consistently. In the Dataset Sources tab, you can add a source URL to the dataset for traceability, and unit validation has been tightened via the Dimensions column. We also streamlined context fields by adding a drop-down list to the Boundary column and moving it to the Emission Dataset tab to keep dataset‑level semantics in one place. For all changes, visit SAP Help: Emission Factors Data.

With the Custom Datasets feature in the Manage Emission Factor app, you can assemble component datasets into a single, composite dataset to derive an overall emission factor when a product or activity’s direct factor is unknown – leveraging known emissions of its parts to enable accurate footprint calculations. Now, those custom datasets also support multi-impact categories, so you can use it also for emission factors beyond climate change. For more information, see Creating Custom Datasets and Emission Factors on SAP Help.

Custom Dataset with Multi-Impact Emission Factors

We’ve also refined the AI-assisted emission factor mapping in the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app. This powerful feature suggests mappings between products (or product groups) from your ERP system and emission factors from LCA databases. A new option, Show Enhanced Footprint Suggestions, is enabled by default and shifts similarity scores to prioritize commodity code first, then text similarity, then country/region. This enhances mapping precision where commodity codes are available. If your ERP master data or LCA packages lack commodity codes, you can switch the option off to revert to text‑matching. Exact matches are elevated when product names and dataset names align and commodity codes are consistent (or both absent), even if descriptions are missing. To reduce false negatives, AI no longer pre‑filters by unit convertibility and you’ll only be blocked at release if unit conversions are missing in product master data. And for categories with sparse activity‑based data, AI now includes spend‑based factors when they rank among the top 10 suggestions. For all details, check SAP Help: Using AI to Map Emission Factors to Purchased Products and Product Groups.

Refined AI-assisted Emission Factor Mapping with Enhanced Footprint Suggestions

 

Other Release Highlights

To help you better understand your transport network at a glance, we added map visualizations for locations and transport routes across key apps. In the Manage Locations app, you can view locations on an interactive map along with details such as address, geocoordinates, postal code, and country or region. The Manage Transport Activities app now also provides a map-based view of generated routes and legs, helping you visualize transport flows more intuitively. On top of that, the Manage Transport Activities and Calculate Transport Footprints apps include an enhanced quick view for locations with an embedded map display. This means you can access location details and see them on a map instantly, streamlining your workflow and saving time.

Visualization of Transport Route and Legs

In my previous blog post, I introduced the Source Input Items feature in the Manage Footprint Results app that gives granular visibility into the inputs driving product emissions to identify hotspots and guide targeted decarbonization actions. We now enhanced this feature with the ability to generate source input items for cyclical calculations. This makes footprint analysis more comprehensive, especially for products calculated based on cyclical processes. On SAP Help, you find more information about source input items: Viewing the Footprint Results, and examples on cycle calculations: Calculating Cycles.

Another update improves data handling and coverage in the Import Business Transactions app: You can now add business transaction data to supplement imported records, with clear tracking of imported and added entries. New columns – Imported Records, Added Records, and Entry Method – provide transparency on how data enters the system, ensuring complete coverage for footprint calculations. The consolidated data (imported and added records) is then used to calculate footprints. For details, see Import Business Transactions, and for more information about business transactions' behavior, see Business Transactions Types on SAP Help.

Finally, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is now available in two additional regions: Europe (Frankfurt) and Brazil (São Paulo), both on AWS. This expansion supports customers operating in these regions with improved availability and compliance.

 

Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide

To make it easier for you to adopt the latest capabilities, we’ve expanded our enablement portfolio with new content and updates across multiple channels. Together with BearingPoint, we hosted a webinar that gives an overall introduction of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and also takes a closer look at multi-impact categories and what they mean for your sustainability strategy. Supported by a system demo, the session explains how these new dimensions help you move beyond carbon to a more holistic view of environmental performance. If you missed it, you can watch the full recording here:

We’ve also updated the Learning Journey Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations. A new unit now explains how to calculate GHG Scope 3.4 emissions using the ERP-centric transport footprint calculation capabilities introduced last year. This addition is particularly valuable for organizations looking to leverage existing ERP data for transport-related emissions without building parallel processes. It’s a practical guide to help you understand how these capabilities fit into your overall footprint model and reporting requirements.

In addition, we also published a new Scenario Guide that includes detailed process steps for calculating Scope 3.4 emissions based on data already available in your ERP systems: Process 8 – Calculating Scope 3.4 Emissions Using Business Transaction Data.

These enablement updates are designed to make adoption easier and faster, so you can focus on turning sustainability data into actionable insights. Whether you prefer learning through webinars, structured journeys, or detailed guides, we’ve got you covered.

 

BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Recently, I joined the Inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud Podcast to discuss sustainability and share real-world examples of how our solutions create impact. A highlight was my conversation with Maximilian Bauer from BASF Coatings, who explained how they use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to tackle the complexity of sustainability in their business.

BASF Coatings operates in a highly dynamic environment, producing thousands of product variations with every color shade counting as a new product. This creates massive data challenges when calculating footprints. With SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, BASF Coatings can now:

  • Scale and automate carbon footprint calculations for hundreds of thousands of products.
  • Integrate seamlessly into existing systems, embedding sustainability into daily operations.
  • Gain actionable insights to offer more sustainable products and make data-driven decisions.

As Maximilian Bauer said: “You can only improve what you can measure – and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management offers us exactly this.”

Looking ahead, BASF Coatings is moving beyond carbon to multi-impact footprints, covering categories like abiotic resource depletion to ensure responsible use of finite resources. They’re also scaling innovations such as biomass balance and ChemCycling®, replacing fossil-based raw materials with renewable or recycled alternatives. These steps position BASF to meet growing global demand for sustainable products and stay ahead of regulatory expectations.

BASF Coatings’ journey illustrates why we’re evolving SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: from carbon-only to multi-impact sustainability footprints, enabling companies to manage risk, cost, and growth across multiple environmental dimensions – all embedded in core business processes.

In the podcast, I also shared our broader vision: embedding sustainability into business processes, leveraging a single trusted data foundation, and using AI to make sustainability intelligent and scalable. By expanding beyond carbon toward multiple impact categories, we help businesses move from compliance to competitive advantage.

Listen to the full episode on Apple Podcast or Spotify.

 

Additional Information

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: News from SAP Activate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the updates to SAP Activate, including the availability of eight roadmaps now offered in nine languages. We’re also excited to share the newly refreshed SAP Activate page on sap.com, which offers a clearer, more intuitive overview of the SAP Activate methodology. This release delivers a range of enhancements across SAP Activate assets, strengthening implementation guidance and improving usability. As always, our focus remains on simplifying and optimizing the implementation journey to provide a more seamless experience for our users. Below are the key highlights for this release:

  • Revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com
  • Eight SAP Activate roadmaps Now Available in Nine Languages
  • SAP Activate Community Blogs and Activate Minute Videos
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • Updates to SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system to 3-system landscape
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2602 Release

 

Revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com

We are excited to announce the launch of the revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com! The updated experience delivers a clearer, more intuitive overview of the SAP Activate methodology, highlighting its phased approach, key benefits, real-world customer successes, and easy access to tools, road maps, and learning resources. Whether you’re just starting your cloud journey or deep into an implementation, the refreshed page makes it easier than ever to understand how SAP Activate helps accelerate transformation and drive faster time-to-value. Explore the new page here and see how SAP Activate continues to evolve to support your success.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Eight SAP Activate roadmaps Now Available in Nine Languages

SAP Activate roadmap content is now available in nine languages, making it easier for our users to consume guidance in the language they are most comfortable with. They can now access roadmap text in German, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and English directly within SAP for ME. This is enabled through Machine Translation, which is now available across eight roadmaps:

  • SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2-system to 3-system)
  • SAP Activate for New Cloud Implementations (Public Cloud – General)

For more details, refer to the blog.

 

SAP Activate Community | SAP Activate Blogs | SAP Activate Minute Videos

Join the SAP Activate Community to explore valuable content and resources while connecting with SAP partners, clients and internal colleagues by participating in discussions and sharing knowledge.

Make sure to follow the SAP Activate tag to access blog posts like those highlighted here, along with additional insights shared by SAP Activate experts within the community.

Recap of some blog posts from the community:

  • Introducing the SAP Activate for SAP Business Network for Logistics roadmap by Ana Goetze
  • SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Content Now Available in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Road Map by Nicole Fuller
  • Deliver quality SAP BTP projects with SAP Activate and partner support services by Jose Bastidas
  • How the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap Answers Your Top 5 Transition Questions by Ana Goetze
  • Who are you? Accountable or Responsible when standing for in the Fit-to-Standard process? by Jair Azevedo
  • RISE with SAP Methodology: A Practical Guide to Modernizing with Confidence by Manuel Lederle
  • Deep Dive: Inside the Framework of RISE with SAP Methodology by Manuel Lederle
  • SAP Activate for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: Scenario-Specific Roadmaps by Kristen Reddington
  • Video: Best Practices to keep up to date on updates and changes in SAP Activate by Jan Musil

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition in 2602

The SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are highlights for this release.

  • Added guidance for system monitoring using SAP Cloud ALM which includes Business Process Monitoring, Integration & Exception Monitoring, User Monitoring, Job & Automation Monitoring, and Health Monitoring. Production Operations Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Expanded the road maps to include a new run phase quality gate and consolidated the adoption plan checklists with the remaining phase gates. All quality gate questions are available as a form in SAP Cloud ALM with enhanced integration to delivery services. Conduct Project Quality Gate for Run Phase
  • Introduced Joule in road map viewer and Joule for Consultants based on Activate content making it more efficient for the customer to find information that they are looking for. 
  • Added a tag to identify the tasks required for the GROW Fast initiative where customers can go live with a fixed scope in 6 weeks.
  • Enhanced the Upgrade of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to include detail related to downward compatibility. Importing configuration transports older than 1 release require SAP support. 3610869 - 3-System Landscape: Downward Compatibility Rule
  • Enable machine translations to provide the content via Road Map Viewer in 6 languages.
  • Included Business AI into the overall implementation methodology by providing easy access to the AI-powered scenarios at the time that they are needed.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for Cloud ERP Private

SAP Activate, the standardized framework for RISE with SAP Methodology, has been enhanced with numerous updates, which are listed in detail in the release notes. The most notable enhancements are the additions of WalkMe and the Transformation Preparation Service, as well as improvements to clean core governance, guidance, and measurement using the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. Additionally, the roadmap viewer has been enhanced with Joule for information retrieval and language translations of SAP Activate content to eight languages, in addition to the content source in English.

Key highlights include:

  • Updated all accelerators to reflect the latest SAP S/4HANA 2025 release content, ensuring alignment with current release, guidance, and best practices across the SAP Activate methodology. 
  • Enhanced guidance for SAP Business Transformation Center by updating tasks, procedure steps, and accelerators to better support selective data transition execution.  
  • Enhanced UX Adoption and User Experience guidance, including updated UX workshops, value discovery accelerators, launchpad design guidance, and stronger linkage between UX strategy and Fit-to-Standard activities. We have updated several tasks to highlight the fact that FIORI/UX is the foundation for Clean Core and AI (like Joule). Additional details available via the User Experience tag.
  • Added a new Mix-and-Match (Selective Data Transition) guidance by updating and tagging key tasks across Prepare to Realize, adding a dedicated tag for Selective Data Transition in Mix-and-Match Scenario. 
  • Refresh of the Project Management workstream, updating purposes, procedures, and templates for governance, planning, sprint execution, phase closure, and multi-country delivery to improve lifecycle consistency. 
  • Expanded extensibility and analytics guidance, adding new accelerators and clearer procedures for key-user extensibility, classic extensibility, embedded analytics discovery, and initial analytics setup. 
  • Improved enablement and learning tasks, with new accelerators for learning needs analysis, enablement strategy, content development, WalkMe solution planning, and removal of redundant or outdated enablement steps. 
  • Refined system conversion and cutover execution clarity, including renamed tasks, updated conversion runbooks, improved readiness assessment guides, clearer cutover procedures, and better differentiation between sandbox, development, test, and production activities.

See the release notes for a complete list of all improvements. 

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform

We’re excited to announce new content in the SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that guides customers on how to design and develop solutions using SAP AI capabilities within SAP BTP. The roadmap now covers the following topics:

  • Incorporate AI and generative AI considerations while shaping the overall SAP BTP implementation approach and governance model
  • Identify where SAP AI services fit within the BTP account structure, environments, and development setup
  • Enable teams to explore AI capabilities alongside core BTP services during early self-learning and sandbox activities
  • Apply AI patterns during application design using ABAP Cloud, CAP, and SAP Build
  • Extend applications with Joule to deliver conversational and productivity-driven user interactions

 

Updates of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system landscape to 3-system landscape 

We are excited to share the latest improvements to the SAP Activate guidance for our customers converting their SAP S/4HANA Cloud from a 2-system landscape to a 3-system landscape. Since the last major release in August 2025, we have made several updates to the guidance based on the learnings from conversion projects and improvements to the conversion process. The key updates are outlined below:

  • Updated task Verify Authorizations in SAP for Me - updated procedure steps and accelerators.
  • Updated task Create and Schedule Test Plan and linked it to the task “Create Test Strategy".
  • Updated task Identify Integrations Scenarios for setup on Test System in the procedure section to explain rebuilding integrations manually or using automation tools.
  • Updated task Create Solution Test Plans with new accelerator for SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation Expert Portal - Test Management.

In addition to the updates mentioned above, the Joule assistant in the road map viewer app has been enabled to support our users with 2SL to 3SL conversion-related questions. When you prompt Joule, remember to include “2SL to 3SL conversion” in the prompt for higher quality results.

We recommend that all users preparing for the upcoming conversion project review the detailed release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer for the latest content updates and view the conversion overview video on the Overview page of the conversion roadmap here.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors

The SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are the highlights:

  • Introduced a quality gate checklist to the end of each phase. All quality gates are available as an interactive form in SAP Cloud ALM and enables enhanced integration to delivery services processes. Conduct Project Quality Gate for Prepare Phase
  • Simplified the task Add Super Admin Access to the SuccessFactors Instance based on process improvements. Linked directly to the help documentation for guidance.
  • Updated Determine Test Scope and other testing related tasks to utilize a process that is standard across multiple solutions.

Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2602 Release

The CE2602 release introduces significant enhancements to Post Upgrade Testing (PUT), including advanced comparison capabilities, improved Test Data Container (TDC) AutoBind integration, and a new scoping capability in i-TS for Smart Execution. Together, these improvements enable smarter automation, more flexible test coverage, and a simplified test setup experience.

Key highlights include:

  • Full Scope Comparison (PUT)
    • Comprehensive Analysis: Compare two complete PUT executions (standard and custom) across different releases or test runs.
    • Side-by-Side Summary: Review execution summaries, triggers, and timestamps in a consolidated view.
    • Impact Identification: Quickly identify post-upgrade changes across the full PUT landscape to support validation and risk mitigation.
  • Comparison of Custom Automates (PUT)
    • Cross-Run Comparison: Compare custom automated PUT test plans executed across two different runs.
    • Instance-Level Status: View detailed execution statuses for each test plan, including Success, Failed, Pre-checks Failed, and Cancelled.
  • Enhanced AutoBind for Test Data Container Integration
    • Intelligent Mapping: Enhanced AutoBind logic automatically maps TDC fields to script labels for both standard and PUT automations.
    • Improved Accuracy: Ensures precise alignment between test data and test scripts.
    • Reduced Manual Effort: Minimizes manual configuration, accelerating test setup.
  • Scoping Capability in i-TS (Smart Execution)
    • Comprehensive Coverage: Combine i-TS recommended processes with standard and custom-defined processes when executing a custom PUT variant, reducing test scope gaps.
    • Flexible Execution: Selectively merge scopes to create a unified test run tailored to specific testing needs.
    • Improved Accuracy: Validates critical i-TS recommended scenarios alongside custom flows for a more reliable post-upgrade assessment.

Overall, these enhancements significantly improve testing efficiency, increase data accuracy, reduce manual effort, and boost productivity across post-upgrade test automation workflows.

Please share with us your feedback and questions in the comments to this blog post or directly via the feedback function in the SAP Activate road map viewer on SAP for Me.

Run simple – SAP Activate – Accelerate and simplify the adoption of SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

entry.title: Q4 2025 Innovations: SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Welcome to the quarterly innovation highlights for  SAP Enterprise Service Management for Q4 2025.  Here, I want to feature some key capabilities that have been released within the past three months. We invite you to register for our Q4 2025 Innovations webcast for SAP Enterprise Management and Service Cloud on Tuesday, January 27th and SAP Sales Cloud and Foundation on Wednesday, January 28th ensuring you stay up-to-date on all the innovations and improvements delivered in Q4 2025.

Also, Learn more about the latest Q4 2025 innovations across the SAP CX portfolio here.

What’s New in SAP Enterprise Service Management
 SAP Enterprise Management is unifying internal service delivery operations across the globe. AI is driving measurable results in workplace productivity and stay tuned for an update on the progress of our ESM@SAP initiative – with already more than 1200 support agents across more than 10 use cases from learning to finance and people and culture using SAP ESM!  Tight integration with the SAP Cloud ERP applications is driving quick deployments, quick time-to-value and bringing users high satisfaction by delivering a truly unified workspace.

Before we jump into the highlights,  please remember to review Kirsi’s Q4 2025 release blog for SAP Service Cloud blog which provides additional innovation highlights benefiting SAP Enterprise Service Management as well!

Now, let me introduce you to some Q4 2025 innovations spanning across useability, extensibility, automation and more!

Personalized KPI Cards in Home Page & Cases:

Personalized KPI cards enables business level configuration of real time app data presented in the home page or in cases to ensure support agents and managers have a pulse on performance. Bringing together information from various applications helps to ensure KPI’s are meaningful and deliver the right insights.

Object-Based Navigation in Mashups

Mashups enable a unified workspace and align various parameters into the business context. However, it is common, especially with custom applications for support agents to work in a separate browser tab.  This navigation enables a quick view to open from custom timeline events in a new browser tab while maintain key parameters.

Navigate to Custom UI’s from Mashups

Ease of navigation is key for support agents. Ensuring processes can be modeled effectively is critical to not only ensure agent satisfaction but to facilitate quick resolutions. Navigation from mashups is now expanded to custom UI’s.

Shortcuts in the Shell Bar

Recent items and favorites have been added to the shortcuts in the shell bar.  Service agents can now access a quick list of their favorites with a click in the shell bar reducing navigation steps. Additionally, an agent can easily retrieve complex tasks or activities they have in-work with one click to view the last 15 recent items. They can bypass menus and searches for one-click access to active work items.

Reference field usage in the Case

The ability to use fields from other entities such as employee, supplier or customer in the case is supports context and processing. Enabling these entities as reference fields in the case processes such as autoflow or rules and in defining customer logic helps streamline processes for the support agent and enables deep context ensuring the right data is considered and included in case resolution steps.

Intent-Based Navigation

Embedded analytics drive key insights to user, now with intent-based navigation a user can go from our embedded SAP Analytics Cloud directly to a case or other entity and make updates without having to click through menu navigation. This truly is “from insights to action,” in just a click or two. Check out more details and a video on Intent-Based Navigation in my colleague Shameek’s blog.  

Case Step Pre-Conditions including Business Documents

Business document integration with SAP Enterprise Service Management creates clean and streamlined experiences for support issues on invoices, disputes and other documents. With the ability to define case step pre-conditions based on values in these business documents case processes and flows can be automated to reflect business document updates.  As an example, if an invoice status changes to 'posted' then a related case can be set to 'closed' automatically without further support.

WalkMe In-App Help

WalkMe is an AI-powered digital adoption platform integrated across SAP Cloud ERP applications and is now integrated with SAP Enterprise Service Management. WalkMe not only accelerates onboarding and new agent training, it enables intuitive, in-app guidance for support agents on-demand. With WalkMe, teams can create step-by-step walkthroughs and contextual tips directly within the application. Additionally, WalkMe provides visibility into where agents encounter friction—helping organizations continuously optimize their service processes.

Form Attachments

An enhancement to the existing dynamic forms capability enables form-based inquiry to include processes-specific documents. Employees or other users can upload relevant documents during request submission reducing follow-ups or additional cycles to gather missing information. As per the case type, the intake form can be defined to designate specific attachments as required reducing errors and reducing risk, especially valuable with  case flows for audits and compliance regulations.

Additional

Use the SAP Enterprise Service Management managed tag when posting on SAP ESM topics! And thank you for your active participation in the community. We all benefit from hearing about successes and challenges with SAP Enterprise Service Management and how you’re using the solution. 

If you feel you have missed some innovations – check the What’s New – and filter by a date range to see all the innovations and improvements  delivered. Never miss an innovation!

entry.title: My First Situation with the Extended Framework
entry.content:
Situation Handling notifies users about issues requiring their attention. With the extended framework for Situation Handling, you can define situations for your business needs.

This blog post illustrates how you can create a situation quickly and with minimal configuration. It outlines the core concept of the extended framework for Situation Handling and guides you in defining your own situation use case.

The configuration relates to the extended framework for Situation Handling which has been available since SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2202 and SAP S/4HANA 2021 FPS2.

 

Introductory Words

The extended framework for Situation Handling is very powerful. In turn, it’s not always easy to get started. To provide you with a straightforward path, this blog post focuses on the minimal viable configuration to create a situation instance.

The Apps

The configuration of Situation Handling is set up across three apps to maximize reuse. While it may seem complex at first, the advantages become clear as you create multiple use cases. The configuration effort decreases substantially with each new use case. The apps also align with different business roles supporting technical and business-oriented responsibilities.

  • Manage Situation Objects – reuse the artifacts from the applications, such as CDS views, events, and navigation targets, for defining a situation object.
  • Manage Situation Scenarios – map the affected object (anchor object) with trigger objects and trigger behaviors create, update, and remove.
  • Manage Situation Types – add logic to the anchor and trigger objects to define the use case

To inform the right users we additionally use the Manage Teams and Responsibilities app.

The Use Case

The extended framework for Situation Handling also comes with a demo app that serves as exploratory sandbox. We use the Situation Handling Demo app and its artifacts for the minimal configuration.

The demo app represents a fictional flight booking system. Your first situation will inform about flights that are scheduled within the next three days.

 

Minimal Configuration

Let’s define the minimal set-up to create a situation.

Manage Situation Objects

The situation object represents a business object. It reuses existing application artifacts that are relevant to your business scope. The core of a situation object is the structure, a CDS view. The CDS view needs to be allowlisted and needs a unique key.

Log-in as Extensibility Specialist to your system and open the app Manage Situation Objects.

Create a new object and enter the object ID, the name, description, and select the SAP object type.

General information of situation object

Then you add the CDS view that contains the data you want to monitor. The CDS view is part of the object’s structure. Create a new structure and enter a description. Select the structure type, the structure name (the reference to the CDS view), and the SAP object node type. For personal data simply select no fields.

CDS structure of situation object

Additionally, you add the semantic key that represents the situation object on the UI. For the flight object we choose the carrier ID, the connection ID and the flight date from the object’s CDS view. It will show, for example, as LH/403/20251224.

Then choose Apply and Create. Your first situation object is set.

Manage Situation Scenarios

The situation scenario relates to the object that is affected by a situation (anchor object). Additionally, it contains the objects that can trigger a situation.

Background:  The trigger object can be the same as the anchor object - for example, if you want to monitor the data of the anchor object’s CDS view. The trigger object can also be another situation object. In our flight example, the trigger object could be the booking object, and the anchor object is the flight.

The trigger object also comes with a trigger behavior. The trigger object can be created or updated; it can also be removed.

In our example, we use the Flight object, both as anchor and as trigger object with the behavior add / update.

Open the app Manage Situation Scenarios.

Create a new scenario with ID, name, and description. Provide the scenario type and the object structure type. You also select the responsibility context ID which links Responsibility Management to Situation Handling to be able to identify the right users who need to be informed about the situation.

General information of situation scenario

Then you add the reference to the object that is affected by the situation, the anchor object. Select the object ID. Chose the object structure ID (an object can have multiple structures) and a key field that uniquely identifies your anchor object. The key field is part of the structure’s CDS view.

Reference to anchor object

Next you define the situation trigger with name and description. As we want to check the CDS fields regularly we create a batch-based trigger.

Batch-based situation trigger

Finally, you need to add the reference to the trigger object like you did for the anchor object. Select the object ID, the object structure ID, and the object key field. Additionally select the relevant object behavior. In our example, it’s add/update because we want to monitor flight data that is new or changed.

Reference to trigger object

Choose Apply and Create. Your scenario is done.

Log-off as Extensibility Specialist and log-in as Business Process Configuration Expert.

Manage Situation Types – Extended

In the  Manage Situation Types – Extended app you define the logic when a situation is detected and who should be informed about it.

Background: The app supports the idea of reuse as well. You can create a situation template that serves as blueprint. And you can derive multiple situation types from it. The blueprint, for example, defines the monitoring of flights. Flight monitoring may require different conditions for different regions. For this purpose, you can derive multiple situation types from the template that contain all settings from the blueprint. You only need to adjust the conditions for the specific regions.

In our use case we want to identify flights that are scheduled within the next three days. Therefore, we want to check the flight data daily and use the batch-based situation trigger from the scenario. In the condition section we define the relevant period of next 3 days.

Open the app Manage Situation Types – Extended.

Create a new template from the scenario My First Scenario. Enter general data that describes the template: the scenario ID, the template ID, the name, and description.

General information of situation template

Then you add the batch-based trigger from the scenario and refine it with conditions. For our use case we simply add a date filter for the next three days.

Condition for situation detection

Now we add the texts that describe the situation for the end user. The situation title and description are used in various places, for example, in My Situations – Extended app, in cards on Fiori launchpad home, and in notifications. We define the title and only use variables to the flight for describing the situation. If we choose to send one notification per situation instance, the same texts are used. The public text My first situation. is added for email notifications (not visible in screenshot).

Situation description for end users

Select Apply.

In the next step we define when the periodical check is scheduled. We define a time zone, a repeat type and interval, and add a start time when the batch is supposed to be scheduled. In the example below, the batch is scheduled every day at 1 am.

Batch-job scheduling

Then we need to define who will be informed about situations. We want to alert users that belong to one or more teams that are responsible for a certain business scope which is expressed by the team category. We use the demo category SITDEMO. Without setting any further filters, all members of the teams belonging to the category would be informed about flights being scheduled within the next three days.

Inform team members about situations

Select Create and your template is complete.

Manage Teams and Responsibilities

Responsibility Management defines who is informed about the situation. Let’s create a simple team and add yourself as a team member.

Open the app Manage Teams and Responsibilities.

Create a new team and enter general data that describes the team: the name (that is also used as global ID), the description, and the type. The type is a sub-group of the team category. Also ensure that you set the status to enabled.

Define a responsible team

Then you add the team members that will be informed about the situations. For the minimal configuration you just add yourself as member.

Members of responsible team

Create the team and log-off as Business Process Configuration Expert.

Log-in as Business Configuration Specialist.

Situation Handling Demo

You can use the data of the Situation Handling Demo app to create a situation. Just open the app and check if the table is already populated with flight data. If not, choose Generate New Data.

Situation Handling Demo app

Manage Situation Types – Extended

Now you create a situation type from the template that will trigger the situation. Usually, types would be further refined or would be a bundle of variants to reflect specific usage. For example, the logic of a template refers to multiple types which address specific sales regions and therefore need specific adjustments in the condition section. In our sample case we simply use the logic of the template as is.

Open the Manage Situation Types – Extended app.

Create a new situation type from the template My First Template. Set the status to enabled and save it.

General information of situation type

On top of the page choose Trigger Batch.

Trigger the batch-job schedule for a situation type

 

Batch-job feedback

In the dialog select Manage Instances. You might need to wait a moment until the batch-job is finalized and refresh the page. Then you see the list of detected situations, that is all flights that are scheduled within the next three days. As a reference you see the semantic keys that you defined within the situation object structure.

List of situation instances in the Manage Situation Types – Extended app

Log-off as Business Process Specialist.

My Situations – Extended

In the My Situation – Extended app the users see all situations in their area of responsibility.

Log-in with the user you added as team member in the Manage Teams and Responsibilities app.

Open the My Situation – Extended  app.

In the left navigation pane select the scenario My First Situation Scenario. The list shows all situations that were detected by the type My First Situation Type. The title My First Situation is the same for all instances. In the description you see the reference to the detected flight, for example, SQ 0160 13.12.2025.

Additionally, you see the new situations indicated next to the notification bell.

List of situations in the My Situations – Extended app

When you select a situation, for example in the list page of the My Situation – Extended app or from the notifications, you go to the situation details page. As the situation description is all we defined, there is no further information to see.

Situation details page in the My Situations – Extended app

You have created your first situations with the minimal configuration. And you have learned which minimal ingredients you need and how they work together.

Next Steps

For further guidance, I recommend reading the following blog posts:

  • Define the optimal information for the end user: Configure the layout of My Situations – Extended.
  • Deep dive into the concept of reusability: The Power of Reuse - Custom Situation Configuration.
  • Explore enhanced configuration options: Custom Situation Cases: Configure Your Own Use Cases.

You find many more blog posts in the Best Practices section of Intelligent Situation Handling in the SAP Community. And you can visit SAP Help for further guidance on Situation Handling.

entry.title: Auto Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery – SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Automatic Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery – SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Nested Handling Units (HUs) mean packing one Handling Unit inside another Handling Unit.
  • For example, cartons packed into a pallet, where each carton and the pallet have their own HU number.

Step 1: Maintain Packaging Material Types. The menu path is shown in the screenshot below.

Note: I have created 2 Packaging Material types:

  • Pallet
  • Carton

Step 2: Define Material group for Packaging Materials

 

  • Created Packing Material groups for Pallet and Carton.

Step 3: Define Allowed Packaging Materials

  • Map the Packing Material Type with the Packing Material Group

  • Note - For Nested HUs, it is mandatory to cross-map Packing Material Types with Packing Material Groups.

This means:

  • Carton groups must allow pallet types, and
  • Pallet groups must allow carton types,
  • so that inner HUs can be packed into outer HUs without errors.

Step 4: Assign Number Range intervals to Packaging Material Type

  • Assign a number range to the created Packing Material Types for the respective plant and storage location.

Step 5: Created packing materials in MM01 using Material Type VERP and assign the relevant Packing Material Group and Pack. Material Type in the “Matl Grp Pack. Matls, Packing Material type” fields under the Basic Data view/Sales: General Plant data. Additionally, assign the appropriate HU Type and also created SFG Material.

In this scenario, two packing materials are created:

  • CARTONBOX with Packing Material Type CARTON
  • PALLET1 with Packing Material Type PALLET
  • 42 with SFG type.

 

Step 6:  Create Packing Instructions using T-Code: POP1

  • Please note that the Handling Unit (HU) number is generated only for the Load Carrier maintained in a Packaging Instruction.
  • As a result, to generate HUs for both cartons and pallets, each must be defined as a Load Carrier. Since a Packaging Instruction can contain only one Load Carrier, separate Packaging Instructions are required for cartons and pallets.
  • Based on this approach, the following Packaging Instructions have been created:

  • Created Packing Instruction “AutoPack”, added Components for Cotton Box.

  • Maintain check profile.

  • Check and save.

  • A separate Packaging Instruction is created for the pallet by adding the PALLET material as Item Category “P” and the AUTOPACK packaging instruction as Item Category “I”. Maintain the required quantities, then check and save.

Step 7: For automatic determination of the Packaging Instruction, create a condition record using T-code POF1.

  • Select “RCPT” standard for Inbound delivery.

  • Assign the SFG material and the ‘PALLET’ Packaging Instruction in the determination record.

Step 8:  Enable Auto Packing in Delivery Types

  • Selected Standard “EL” delivery type for Inbound delivery
  • Enabled “Automatic Packing” and save

The above are the configuration steps. The functional flow is explained below.

  • Created PO by selecting Confirmation key.

  • Create the inbound delivery, select the line item, and click ‘Auto Packing’. The system automatically packs the material.

In this scenario, Material 42 – SFG Material is maintained.

  • Each Carton Box is defined to carry 25 KG of SFG material.
  • Multiple Carton Boxes are then packed into a Pallet, where one pallet contains 4 carton boxes.
  • A Purchase Order is created for 100 KG of 42 SFG material.

During Inbound Delivery Auto Packing, the system performs the packing automatically as follows:

  • 100 KG of SFG material is packed into 4 Carton HUs (25 KG each).
  • These 4 Carton HUs are nested and packed into 1 Pallet HU.

This demonstrates Nested Handling Unit (HU) auto packing, where inner Carton HUs are packed into an outer Pallet HU, and each level is assigned its own HU number automatically by the system.

entry.title: SAP Joule implementation in an S/4HANA private cloud 3 system landscape
entry.content:
While most customers choose to activate and run SAP Joule in a single-system S/4HANA Private Cloud landscape, I had the opportunity to implement it across a complete three-system landscape—DEV, QAS, and PRD. This approach brought additional complexity in terms of transport, configuration consistency, and cross-system validation, but it also ensured a more robust, production-ready deployment. Successfully enabling Joule in a full landscape setup is not just a technical task; it reflects a deeper understanding of SAP architecture, governance, and best practices. Delivering this implementation end-to-end has been a noteworthy achievement in my SAP journey. 

Sharing this experience is important because a three-system setup brings its own challenges, and I hope this blog will make the process clearer and easier for anyone working in a similar landscape. 

The steps for implementing Joule remain the same across landscapes, but there are several important considerations that need to be planned in advance before starting the implementation in a customer environment. 

Let’s get started. 

Architecture diagram 

1. BTP subaccounts and Cloud identity service 

For non-production systems (development and quality systems), we need to create two different subaccounts for each to enable the required Joule and Work Zone subscriptions and services. This separation helps maintain a clear landscape structure aligned with the backend systems.  However, it is recommended to use a common subaccount for the Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant, as it has only one connectivity service, and identity management should remain centralized for consistent user provisioning and authentication across both environments, and we are using non prod IAS tenants for both. 

 Tip: We can also integrate Joule without creating a separate subaccount for CIS by including CIS in the individual DEV and QA subaccounts, but in that case we need to create the RFC for the identity service from the DEV subaccount for the QA system by pointing this RFC to the QA system used when configuring the source system in IAS. 

2. SAP roles assignment to users 

Since Joule-specific capabilities are embedded within certain standard SAP roles, it’s important to ensure that end users who will be accessing Joule have these roles assigned. Without the required role assignments, users will not be able to utilize Joule’s features fully. For most customers, users already have their standard Fiori roles assigned based on their functional area—for example, a finance user typically has all the roles required for their day-to-day activities. 

Tip: Get a list of all the roles from the customer security team and make sure these roles are exposed to BTP in all three systems. It’s better to involve the security team here to get this step done. 

3. Technical and business catalog creation 

This step must be carried out in the development system. The technical and business catalogs required for the QA and PRD systems will also be created in DEV and then transported to the respective systems as part of the normal transport process. During production cutover activities make sure the transports for catalogs are moved to production systems. 

 Tip: If we are configuring Joule in unit test clients other than the DEV client, create catalogs and roles in the development client and then create a client copy transport to the Joule configuration client in the development system. The same applies for any other developments as well. 

4. Joule plugin role 

It is recommended to create three separate single roles for Joule when working in a three-system landscape. The business catalog created in the development system should be included in the DEV-specific role, and the corresponding catalogs for QA and PRD should be added to their respective roles and transported through the landscape. Assigning users the appropriate role for each system ensures that they can see the Joule icon upon logging into the Fiori Launchpad. This approach is essential to ensure that Joule correctly points to the intended BTP subaccount and retrieves data from the corresponding S/4HANA system. 

5. OData services activation 

Based on the required capabilities, identify the corresponding OData services that need to be activated in the system. Activate these services first in the development system, capture them in a transport request, and move the transport to the QA and PRD systems. In some cases, even after the transport is imported, the related ICF services may not be automatically activated in QA or PRD. In such situations, you must manually activate the ICF services. Ensure that the necessary authorizations are available for performing this activation. 

6. Cloud connector principal propagation 

Principal propagations set up in cloud connectors are an important step in Joule configuration. Make sure this is done in Non-Prod and Prod cloud connector.  During production cutover, we must obtain the required access to the production system to check the related parameters, CERTURLE, and certificates in the system. We must ensure access for this and get the fire fighter user if the normal user does not have the required authorization. For most production environments, there will be web dispatchers, and in such cases, we need to import the Cloud Connector certificates into the web dispatchers as well 

7. SSO for Joule 

In most production landscapes, customers expect Single Sign-On (SSO) to be enabled for Joule.  If an S/4HANA system is already configured for SSO using Microsoft Entra ID, you can extend the same setup to Joule by configuring Microsoft Entra ID as the corporate identity provider in SAP IAS and setting it as the default identity provider. Once this is done, SSO for Joule is automatically enabled. Users do not need to exist in the IAS user store for Joule to function, as authentication flows directly through Microsoft Entra ID. 

By taking care of all these steps, you can ensure a smooth and successful Joule implementation across a three-system landscape.

entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public Cloud vs S/4HANA Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to choose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Public Cloud or S/4HANA Private Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed, while S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organisation's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the ultimate destination. This due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope, reduced system control and the need to leave customisations and certain data behind.

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud vs Private Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment in collaboration with SAP or your Partner.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organisations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your clear way forward. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardised, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAP‑controlled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (no Hyperscaler selection). If the organisation has a particular requirement for any of these or for an overall operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Private Cloud might be better suited.

    While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are of paramount importance for a Public Cloud deployment.

    All that said, the value and fit of Private Cloud for certain organisations should not be overlooked. Many enterprises, especially those with regulatory constraints, multi‑layered integrations, high customisation, heavy data volumes, or deep industry-specific implementation scope, continue to find Private Cloud more practical and in cases the only suitable option.

    To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAP’s Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation vs system conversion is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you establish the right company culture, then lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud. Otherwise, in case of unique requirements and a more complex landscape, S/4HANA Private Cloud might be a better fit. 

    Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.

entry.title: IFRS 18 Is Coming: What Finance Teams Need to Know TODAY
entry.content:
IFRS 18, the new international reporting standard, is on the horizon—and it’s set to reshape how companies present financial performance. Replacing IAS 1, the new standard introduces clearer categories in the income statement, greater transparency around management-defined performance measures, and more consistency across global reporting.

For finance leaders, this isn’t just an accounting change. It’s a strategic shift requiring updates to reporting processes, systems, internal controls, and guidance for business stakeholders. With implementation deadlines approaching, now is the time to assess readiness and begin planning the transition. The companies that prepare early will benefit from stronger insights and more credible financial communication.
